page.title: 03Courteenhall Church
page.content: The parish church dedicated to St. Peter and St. Paul is 900 years old though the font is Saxon. The north pillars and South door are Norman whilst the Chancel and south porch are 14th century and the tower, which has a ring of five bells, is 15th Century. The church had a very high pulpit and box pews but these were removed during 19th Century modernisation. The names and dates of the Rectors and Patrons are recorded since 1272. Notable features of the church include the leper window, which allowed lepers to partake in the service without entering the church; the organ, renovated in 1981 which stands on the Wake family vault; and the busts of Sir Samuel Jones & his wife, who gave the village its school in 1680.
